results.title: Getting in on the Act
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Managing the Micro”.
Looks at how microelectronics can be introduced into a produce or process, what skills are needed, and what risks are involved. Also how management can get enough of an idea to be able to talk sensibly about the technology. Illustrative material includes film of a successful engineering company and a micro-controlled greenhouse. A studio demonstration explores what would be involved in designing, developing and making a proposed new product - a micro-controlled piano tuner

results.title: Thinking Small
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Managing the Micro”.
A chance to explore the opportunities which microelectronics offers large, medium and small companies, explaining how the technology differs from earlier technology and what its characteristics are. Case studies include a garment maker, a paper mill, a woodyard and a major manufacturer of tailor-made equipment using computer-aided design and manufacture

results.title: The Goya effect
results.creator_credit: Michael Tuchner, Ian Latimer and Rank Aldis Industrial Services
results.brief_description:
Episode number 7 of Series “Manager in Action”.
Demonstrates the limitations of formal information systems. Highlights the importance of spending time at the “sharp” end and the role of non-verbal signals in face to face communication. Intended for middle and junior managers in industrial and commercial organisations.

results.title: Time to think
results.creator_credit: Peter Hammond, Anthony Pelissier and Rank Organisation Short Films Group
results.brief_description:
Episode number 3 of Series “Manager in Action”
A dramatised version of daily office routines showing how a manager can delegate tasks to other staff leaving major considerations to be dealt with more thoroughly.

group_works.title: Investment planning
group_works.creator_credit: David Hargreaves, Paul Ellis and BBC-TV

results.title: Controlling stocks
results.brief_description:
Episode number 4 of Series “Management Techniques”.
One of a series of films about some of the problems of forecasting, and of trying to achieve control through forecasts, particularly in the case of small and medium-sized firms. Carrying excessive stocks can be expensive, whilst insufficient stocks may cause loss of customer confidence. Shows how to strike a reasonable balance of stock holdings.

results.title: Seeing the future
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Management Techniques”.
One of a series of films about some of the problems of forecasting, and of trying to achieve control through forecasts, particularly in the case of small and medium-sized firms. Intuition and detached statistical forecasts are both highly vulnerable to the unexpected. Unless this limitation can be overcome, forecasting is of no use to management.

results.title: Producing a plan
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Management Techniques”.
One of a series of films about some of the problems of planning, and of trying to achieve control through forecasts, particularly in the case of small and medium-sized firms. Most critical production decisions are made before anything has been produced. Care must be taken to avoid vital errors in such things as shop floor layout when plans are first made.

results.title: Investment planning
results.creator_credit: David Hargreaves, Paul Ellis and BBC-TV
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Management Techniques”.
Aims to clarify some of the problems of forecasting for managers of small and medium-sized businesses, thereby achieving control through forecasts. An investment policy is a plan for the future, and as such it needs to be both simple and effective.
results.description:
Episode of Series “Management Techniques”.
